characters: INT. BRANCASTER CASTLE AND DOWNTON. SMALL HALL. DAY
INT. POST OFFICE. DOWNTON VILLAGE. DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert is coming down with the dog Teo as Thomas enters t hall. He stops to take the letters from the salver.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Just arrived, m’lord. There’s one from Buckingham Palace.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Heavens.  He walks into the dining room. We hear Mary speaking.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But we really need to cut back until the farms repay the investment. And we must make a plan for the roof. Robert is reading the letter, standing by the sideboard.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Well, this won't help us to economise.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: The King and Queen are coming to stay. He helps himself.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What? During their Yorkshire tour?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: That's it. Just for a night. They'll spend one night at Downton and then go on to Harewood for a ball. While they're here, there's to be a parade of the Yorkshire Hussars in the village. Is there any chance Henry might be back?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I doubt it. I'll send a telegram. But there's a motor show in Chicago that I know he cannot chuck. Robert sits to eat and gives some bacon to Teo.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Tom, you're keeping your enthusiasm under control. Is this the Irish patriot making a reappearance?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I know you find my opinions highly entertaining.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I suppose they'll send people to check that Mrs Patmore isn't a Russian spy. Will you tell them downstairs, Barrow? I'll see to Her Ladyship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, m'lord. INT. KITCHEN/KITCHEN PASSAGE. DOWNTON. DAY. Mrs Hughes and Mrs Patmore are with Daisy and Andy.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: A Royal luncheon, a parade and a dinner? I'm going to have to sit down. What about Mr Branson?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Well, he’s a Republican, isn’t he?

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Should Mr Carson look in, no one is to say that word in front of him. She walks out, into the kitchen passage.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I agree with Mr Branson. I don't like kings either. I suppose that makes me a republican too.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Are the English allowed to be? EXT. BRANCASTER CASTLE. NORTHUMBERLAND. DAY. Edith is driving herself towards the castle.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Two weeks to get ready? Golly.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BRANCASTER CASTLE AND DOWNTON. SMALL HALL. DAY
dialogues.text: Edith and Cora speak to each other on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: It's quite an honour.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: It is. But if I know anything about Royal visits, we will never stop changing our clothes.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I've just been on a buying spree, which is good. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Handley-Seymour is making me a ball dress, so I'll get her to hurry it up.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Have her send it here. How are things otherwise?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Oh, you know. I've got a luncheon for thirty today in aid of the lifeboats. Or is that tomorrow? Anyway, it's in aid of something.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Sounds like business as usual. I'll see you soon, darling. EXT. THE CARSONS’ COTTAGE. DAY. Carson works on a vegetable patch. Mrs Hughes joins him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: You know I can bring back as many vegetables as we could eat.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I like to keep busy. How have they taken the news up at the house?

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Daisy's singing "The Marseillaise", so no surprises there. What's the matter? I thought you'd be pleased.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I am pleased. The visit is a great honour. But members of the Royal and Imperial Household are coming to Downton who will have visited the greatest houses in the land. Blenheim, Chatsworth, Arundel. Does Mr Barrow know what he's taking on?

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Why should it affect you? You're not in charge anymore. Now come in for your lunch and let me get back. She does not see that Carson looks as if she has struck h EXT. KING’S ARMS. DOWNTON VILLAGE. DAY. Major Chetwode walks in, carrying a suitcase.  INT. A ROOM AT THE KING’S ARMS. DOWNTON VILLAGE. DAY. The door opens and Chetwode is shown in by a landlady.

dialogues.speaker: LANDLADY
dialogues.text: All right, sir. Here we are.

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: This will do very well. Thank you. He puts his case on the bed. The landlady gives Chetwode key and leaves. Chetwode goes to the window. The room loo out over the green. EXT. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY. Swans swim in the lake near the palace. INT. BUCKINGHAM PALACE. DAY. A footman opens the gilded door. The Queen looks up.

dialogues.speaker: FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: The Lady Bagshaw, Your Majesty. Maud Bagshaw has a kind face but a determined one.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: Good. We'll go to the 1844 room as soon as they're here. Do sit down. Maud and Queen Mary move to the sitting area. Maud holds folder.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I've just received the plan for the tour of Yorkshire, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. It's just been finalised. I think we'll enjoy it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I didn't realise we would be staying at Downton Abbey.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: Only for a night. There's to be a parade and a dinner and then we go on to Princess Mary at Harewood.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I just wondered if I might, perhaps, go straight to Harewood. Queen Mary is rather surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Grantham is my cousin and the two families have... fallen out. Or at least we might if I were there in person.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: And what would cause this quarrel?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Lord Grantham's mother believes her son should be my heir.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: Old Lady Grantham can be very hard to resist, as I am well aware.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Exactly, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: But surely they need to know if their hopes are to be disappointed. INT. KITCHEN. DOWNTON. EVE. Mrs Patmore is with Daisy, Anna and Mrs Hughes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: I wish I knew if they like simple food or fancy.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I can't think they'll want simple food. With that sort, don't they like sauces and everything velouté and frappé and smothered in cream?

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: "That sort"? He's the King of England! There's only one of them in the world. "That sort" indeed!

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Don't plan too much. Not until we know what's expected.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Well, I know what's expected of me-- food. You too, Daisy. So less philosophy, more elbow grease. Andy enters with an empty tray. He heard this.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Is the pudding ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is. Daisy take the soufflés out of the oven while I find my specs.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: This country needs a shake-up.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: You should run for Parliament. Daisy scoffs.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why not? Lady Astor's done it.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: And so an under cook from Yorkshire is bound to follow her.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: You've got to have big dreams.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: But do you have big dreams, Andy?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I've not offended you, have I?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Well, for a start, you never talk about the wedding anymore.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: We'll get wed when we're good and ready and not before.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: But, you see, I am ready.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Take those up before they collapse. He goes. Mrs Patmore has been listening. INT. DINING ROOM. DOWNTON. EVE. Andy and Thomas serve. Violet, Isobel and Merton are amon the party.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Maud Bagshaw is coming to Downton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, as the Queen's lady-in- waiting.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Oh, my goodness.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why so surprised? Who is she?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: She's a cousin of your father's. Violet hesitates slightly. She glances at Thomas and Andy VIOLET (CONT’D) We'll discuss it later.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You're not to make things awkward.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: How's it all going?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Mary's got it under control.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Hardly. There's so much to do.

dialogues.speaker: MERTON
dialogues.text: Who were those men measuring on the green as we came past?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They're building the dais for the Queen at the parade.

dialogues.speaker: MERTON
dialogues.text: How exciting.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: It seems rather a waste of money.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Isn't that what the Monarchy's for? To brighten the lives of the Nation with stateliness and glamour?

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: To quote Tennyson, "Kind hearts are more than coronets, And simple faith than Norman blood."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you have enough clichés to get you through the visit?

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: If not, I'll come to you. INT. DRAWING ROOM. DOWNTON. NIGHT. They have their coffee and other drinks and the servants leave them. Teo is lying by the fire. Violet sits in stat

dialogues.speaker: MERTON
dialogues.text: And now, you were going to tell us about Lady Bagshaw. Is she a very distant cousin?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No. Her father was my great-uncle.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Then why have I never heard of her?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Because she chose to cut herself off from the family.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Do you know the reason?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Maybe. I believe she means to cheat your father of his rightful inheritance. She has no children. Your father is her nearest relation.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I won't have her put on the spot.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: You're plotting something. I see a Machiavellian look in your eye.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Machiavelli is frequently underrated. He had many qualities.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: So did Caligula, not all of them charming.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What are you up to, Granny?  10.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Ideally, I would like Maud to see your father as the son she never had.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Will she be the mother I never had?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Sarcasm is the lowest form of wit. INT. KITCHEN PASSAGE/SERVANTS’ HALL. DOWNTON. NIGHT. The servants are finishing dinner when Molesley appears.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Mr Molesley, it's very late for you to be out. Molesley is breathless.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: Is it true?

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Is what true, Mr Molesley?

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: Mr Bakewell said that you'd warned him that there was to be a Royal visit.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Well, now I know who not to trust with a secret.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: That we should deserve such honour!

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Not you too. I am disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Ignore her.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: I wonder, do you think I might be allowed to slip on my livery again?

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Would the school let you?

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: They'll give me time for this, I promise.  11.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Let's wait ‘til we know our orders.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: What about it, Mr Barrow? Will you let me wait upon my King and Queen?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Uh, well-- Bell rings.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: That’s us. He is stumped for words. Anna has taken in his terror.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Good night, Mr Molesley Molesley goes, flabbergasted. Bates stands.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: When we're done, shall I fetch Johnnie, or will you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I can fetch him. They leave. Daisy and Mrs Patmore are left alone.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: How exciting.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: They're all mental. All this fuss for a man and woman we don't even know.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Never mind that. I wanted to tell you: I've had some ideas about what to serve at your wedding.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Stop going on about my wedding. INT./EXT. MONTAGE. DOWNTON. DAY. Curtains are taken down, rugs are taken up. Maids make be scrub, polish.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We've only a few days left, so I spoke to Her Ladyship and she's agreed our normal rules should be suspended. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won't clean a room if a family member is using it, but otherwise, all restrictions are lifted. No detail should be left undone, however small. INT. SERVANTS’ HALL. DOWNTON. DAY. 12. Mrs Hughes is still addressing the whole staff at the tab

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: I want every surface in this house to gleam and sparkle by Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Blimey.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Can I have your attention, please? At four this afternoon, Their Majesties' butler, Mr Wilson, will be coming over from Raby Castle with a lady's maid and a valet.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: To give us our instructions?

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: With the Royal servants, are we to wait on them?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: That is what will be made clear.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I won't be waiting on any valets and lady's maids, thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Before we get hot under the collar, let's just wait and see what they have to say.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Amen. EXT. CAR SHOWROOM. YORK. DAY. The man we saw earlier, Chetwode, is watching as Branson opens up. Chetwode crosses the road.  13. INT. CAR SHOWROOM. YORK. DAY. Branson is taking off his gloves and coat when the man enters.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Can I help you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: It's really you I came to see. He is a British officer type, in tweeds, with a slight dr

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: How can I help you, Mr...?

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: Chetwode. Major Chetwode. Am I right, you're Mr Branson, Lord Grantham's son-in-law?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I am. Chetwode nods. It is hard to tell where this is going.

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: The papers tell me the King and Queen will be staying at Downton Abbey during their tour of Yorkshire.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Well, if it's in the papers, it must be true.

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: Yes, a great honour. Although, as an Irishman, you may feel differently.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I know when my parents-in-law have been paid a compliment.

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: There's to be a military parade, I gather. How do you feel about that?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: What do you mean, "how do I feel"?

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: Only you didn't say whether you support them. The King and Queen.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I support Lord Grantham.  14.

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: Very neat. Until we meet again, Mr Branson. Branson has the feeling he has been tried and found wanti INT. THE SILVER PANTRY. DOWNTON. DAY. Thomas is staring at a vast display of silver. Mary enter

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Ah, Barrow. They said you'd be in here. Heavens! We can still put on quite a show when we need to, I'm glad to see. Has it all been cleaned?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: More or less everything's been done to a basic level, m'lady, but we haven't done the final buffing-up.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: I was waiting for Their Majesties' butler. I thought I'd ask his advice on what to use on the table.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Really? Can't we decide what we lay on our own dining table? The door opens and Andy looks in.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Front doorbell, Mr Barrow.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Please, go.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: M' lady. Thomas leaves Mary in the pantry. EXT. DOWNTON. DAY. Mr Wilson stands before a gleaming car with the valet and maid, Ellis and Lawton. Thomas opens the door and comes o

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Greetings, Mr Wilson. Welcome to Downton Abbey.  15. Wilson looks at the house disdainfully. Wilson, Ellis and Lawton walk past Thomas, into the house. Thomas follows. INT. HALL. DOWNTON. DAY. Mary crosses the hall as Thomas enters with Wilson and th others. Her eyes meet Thomas’s. She raises her brows.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: This way, Mr Wilson. INT. LIBRARY. DOWNTON. DAY. Mary enters, taking Caroline from the nanny. The family i already having tea. George plays draughts with Robert. Branson has Sybbie. Cora is reading a letter.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The Royal butler's terribly scary. Barrow looked like a rabbit in front of a cobra.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Oh, dear. Should I go down?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: They know what they're doing.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Do they? They're hideously behind. There's a mark on the Blue Room carpet we can't shift, I have no chairs for the parade, and we haven't even decided on the footmen.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I'm going to have another cup, if no one's coming up to serve.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: This is nice. Princess Mary wants us for tea tomorrow at Harewood.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I've got so much to do.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: I wonder if that means the young couple have taken over the big house?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: They're hardly the "young couple". Well, he isn't anyway.  16.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: She always seems quite shy to me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: A shy Royal? Is that an oxymoron?

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Anyway, we're going. INT. SERVANTS’ HALL. DOWNTON. DAY. Wilson is addressing the household. Molesley’s not there Mr Ellis and Miss Lawton, are.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: I will return to Raby Castle and come back to Downton in advance of Their Majesties on Thursday. But His Majesty's valet, Mr Ellis, and Her Majesty's dresser, Miss Lawton, will stay on, if that is convenient. Or they can put up in the village.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: No, we'll find them rooms.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Then Monsieur Courbet, the chef--

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, "Mr Courbet, the chef"?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: That's right. We'd be very grateful if you could make the kitchens ready.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: So what should I order?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Nothing. He will bring it all.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: And we don't cook any of the food?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Cook for the servants. Monsieur Courbet won't have time for that.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Oh, I say! That is something to look forward to!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm yourself, Mrs Patmore. If it's the way these things are done...

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Mrs Webb and four footmen will arrive with Monsieur Courbet the day before.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Who is this... Mrs Webb, is it?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: She is the housekeeper. She will also bring two maids with her.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: The housekeeper?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: While Their Majesties are here.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: And the maids?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: They will make the beds, clean the bathrooms, that sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: I see. So my maids and I will not be involved in the preparations?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: You mean, during the stay you'll be the butler, and--

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I am not a butler. I am the King's Page of the Backstairs. They almost reel. Daisy rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: So our staff has nothing to do.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: I'm sure they can be useful.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: How can they eat and get dressed at Raby Castle if the chef and the valet and the maid are all here? 17.  18.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: We have two of each. The principal valet and the principal dresser will arrive in advance of Their Majesties, who bring an equerry, a lady-in-waiting, two detectives and two chauffeurs. The other chef goes from Raby to Harewood. Four footmen go with him and the other four come here. Do you all understand me? No, judging by their expressions. EXT. DOWNTON ESTATE. DAY. Violet is walking with Isobel.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: You can hardly heckle Lady Bagshaw in front of the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to prevent a crime.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Who says it’s a crime?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Oh, and you're an expert in the matter?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I am an expert in every matter.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: You must have some idea why she doesn't want Robert as her heir.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I have none. He is her closest relative. The family have held Brompton for three centuries. But she wants to give it to who? Charity? The dogs' home?

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: I would have thought the family had enough to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: That's not the point.  19.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Very well. We must try and discover her reasons.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What possible reasons can there be?

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: That's what I intend to find out. INT./EXT. THE CARSONS’ COTTAGE. DAY. Carson is with Mrs Hughes. There’s a knock. Mary is outsi He leads her inside.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Carson.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: M'lady. Please, come in. This is an honour.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I don't want to be a nuisance, but I need your help, Carson. Barrow just isn't up to the task.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: M' lady?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He won't clean the silver. Or he won't let Andrew clean it.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He says the page of the... thingummy will choose which pieces to use.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The truth is, he's in a sort of trance. Won't you help me? I feel I'm pushing a rock uphill.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I'll be there in the morning, m'lady. Don't you worry.  20.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You're a treasure, Carson. That's all there is to say. I'll see myself out. She slips away.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: You could never refuse her anything. And what about Mr Barrow?

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Mr Barrow can like it or lump it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Then I'm afraid he'll lump it. Carson sits, pleased. INT. MENSERVANTS’ BEDROOM CORRIDOR/ELLIS’ ROOM. EVE. Thomas leads Ellis to his room.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: We have supper after the upstairs dinner, so you've plenty of time.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: How does it work with two valets?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: I prepare His Majesty's clothes and uniforms for Downton. Then, when Mr Miller arrives, I get the stuff for Harewood ready. Then I head back to London and prepare for their return. It all overlaps.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: So, Mr Miller's the one who actually dresses the King?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: Unless he's ill. Then it's me.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Is he often ill?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: No. Which makes them both laugh.  INT. KITCHEN/KITCHEN PASSAGE. DOWNTON. NIGHT. Mrs Patmore is by the sink. Daisy is with her.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I think it's rubbish. They impose, they demand, and now we're to be made nothing in our own house.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: It's very disappointing, I won't deny it. This water's not too hot. Have they all been having baths?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: How should I know? 21. She walks into the passage where Anna and Bates are waiti Bates carries their little boy. Thomas is coming downstai

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Mr Barrow, don't you think you should speak to His Lordship?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Well, it's not right, surely, for us to be humiliated in this way.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: What could he do about it? He walks off.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Is the staff always ridden over roughshod whenever Royalty come to stay? Why do they bring so many servants with them?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Maybe it's because they go from house to house around the county and they need to know things are done the way they like.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: As if we couldn't manage that.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: We're not footballs, Mr Bates, and we don't deserve a kicking.  22. EXT. THE PARK. DOWNTON. DAY. Carson strides purposefully up the drive, like a proud ki returning to claim his throne. INT. LIBRARY. DOWNTON. DAY. Robert is with Mary.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: But what are we to say to Barrow? After all, he's done nothing wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He's done nothing at all. That's the problem.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: But it feels very unfair. Carson enters the library, clearing his throat to announc himself. ROBERT (CONT’D) Oh, I see. So it's now.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I've sent down for Mr Barrow to join us, m'lord. The door opens and Thomas comes in. The sound

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: You wanted to see me, m'lord? Mr Carson! What brings you here?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Well, this is the thing...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Carson is going to move back into the house for the Royal visit.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: What? of the word is very bald. He stares at Carson.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are coming back here as butler, when I am the butler here?

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Yes, that is--  23.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Can I ask how long this has been planned, m'lord?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I wouldn't say it's been exactly planned.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Because I don't quite understand where it leaves me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Well, you can be a sort of--

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: With your permission, I'd prefer not to be a "sort of" anything, m'lord. I will surrender my position for the duration of the visit, if I must, and serve you again when Their Majesties have gone, if you so wish.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Please don't think that-- But Thomas has made up his mind. He walks towards the doo

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: By the way, the boiler's playing up and there's no hot water.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: God, that's all we need.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Now, Barrow-- He leaves in a white rage, more or less slamming the door

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Not to worry. The plumber will soon have it mended, m'lady, and we'll bring water jugs up to the bedrooms tonight and in the morning. It can't be that hard. We did it for three hundred years.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Thank you, Carson. Well, that went well.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Will you sack him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. As a matter of fact, I was quite interested. I never thought of him as a man of principle before. EXT. DOWNTON VILLAGE. DAY. A new day. Mrs Patmore and Daisy are on the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: I'll have to tell him I'm only ordering for the servants' hall. I'm afraid I've got his hopes up. They walk into Mr Bakewell’s shop. INT. BAKEWELL’S SHOP. DOWNTON VILLAGE. DAY. 24. Mr Bakewell is serving Molesley. He is delighted to see h

dialogues.speaker: BAKEWELL
dialogues.text: Speak of the devil! Come in, come in. I was just saying you'll be wanting to finalise the order.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Were you, indeed?

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: Honestly, no one in the village can talk about anything else!

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: BAKEWELL
dialogues.text: I know it's a bit of a liberty, but I've made a list of all the ingredients of your favourite dishes. I know them well enough after all these years, but some things will have to be brought in, so we should really get on with it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: I appreciate everything you've done, Mr Bakewell-- Mr Bakewell laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BAKEWELL
dialogues.text: My heart is fit to burst, I don't mind telling you. I shall have fed the King Emperor from my own shop. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BAKEWELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If only my father were alive. He'd be so proud of me. He would. He is almost crying.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: I'm sure he'd be proud of you anyway, Mr Bakewell.

dialogues.speaker: BAKEWELL
dialogues.text: Oh, no, not like this. No. This is the peak of my career. The peak of my life, really. Everyone's so jealous. Now, I've put ticks next to the ones I think you'll go for.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: The thing is--

dialogues.speaker: BAKEWELL
dialogues.text: I'm guessing the luncheon will be for around a dozen? Of course, the dinner will be larger. Let's say thirty or thereabouts? You'll correct me if I'm wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Well, you see--

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: You're not wrong, Mr Bakewell. But we'll say if the numbers change. Mrs Patmore stares at her but Daisy is defiant.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The pavlova's not realistic. We'd be safer with a charlotte russe. We can do most of the work before.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: And I shall be serving! Think of that! He bursts into song, waltzing with Mrs Patmore.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sings) I've danced with a man who's danced with a girl who's danced with the Prince of Wales I'm crazy with excitement, completely off the rails  26.

dialogues.speaker: BAKEWELL
dialogues.text: All of my suppliers are so excited. Oh, Mrs Patmore, I shall never be able to thank you enough. Not if I live to be a hundred. EXT. DOWNTON VILLAGE. DAY. They emerge from the shop doorway and walk away.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: I feel like a liar. I should go back.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: And lower yourself to a kitchen skivvy in the eyes of the village? Never mind ruining Mr Bakewell's year. You'll do no such thing. She stamps off. Mrs Patmore hesitates. EXT. DOWNTON. DAY. Robert, Cora, Mary, Andy, Albert, Carson and Mrs Hughes w as a car comes to a halt. Edith, Bertie and Marigold clim out.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No maid, no valet, no nanny, even.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: It's nineteen twenty-seven. We're modern folk.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Nanny will take care of Marigold. And Anna can look after you.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Really? Can she?

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Of course. Just like the old days. Granny's here, and Isobel, and we're paying a call this afternoon on Princess Mary.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Has my new ball dress arrived?

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Not yet, but it will.  27. INT. BOOT ROOM. DOWNTON. DAY. The Queen’s dresser, Lawton, is cleaning shoes with Anna. Bates is in there, polishing a pair of Robert's.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: How long have you worked for Her Majesty, Miss Lawton?

dialogues.speaker: LAWTON
dialogues.text: Six years.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: How interesting. I expect you're a skilled needlewoman for that job. Lawton’s pitying, smug smile confirms the truth of this.

dialogues.speaker: LAWTON
dialogues.text: I've had no complaints. I trained under Madame Lucile. Her Majesty wanted a professional dressmaker.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: And they found you?

dialogues.speaker: LAWTON
dialogues.text: My reputation found me. Anna catches Bates’ eye. He giggles. Lawton doesn’t notic INT. DINING ROOM. DOWNTON. DAY. The end of luncheon. Carson is supervising. Cora stands.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Come on, you two, it's nearly three. We ought to get ready.

dialogues.speaker: MERTON
dialogues.text: Will the Princess be at the parade?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: They both will.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: I always find her rather sad, Princess Mary.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: She is Royal. Royal women are not meant to grin like Cheshire cats.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: They don't have to look miserable.  28.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: To you she looks miserable. To me she looks dignified.

dialogues.speaker: MERTON
dialogues.text: Doesn't that say it all?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: How comforting to see you here, Carson. What prompted you to take up the flaming sword again?

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I felt I should go where I could do the most good, m'lady.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Wise words for all of us. They have risen now and they are leaving the room. EXT. HAREWOOD HOUSE. YORKSHIRE. DAY. The splendid palace sits comfortably in its setting. A ca drives up. The three women walk from their car to the entrance. INT. DRAWING ROOM. HAREWOOD HOUSE. DAY. A footman announces the family. They have shed their coat but retained their hats and they carry their gloves.

dialogues.speaker: FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: The Marchioness of Hexham, the Countess of Grantham, the Lady Mary Talbot. They advance towards a rather sad-looking woman of thirty near the fire. They sink into deep court curtseys.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Your Royal Highness.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: Please, sit down, Lady Grantham. I suppose you're in turmoil because of my parents' visit. I do sympathise.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: We don't need to explain it to you.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: Just don't paint anything. They're sick of the smell of new paint.  29.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I hope it's not too late.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Are you living here now, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: No, we're still at Goldsborough. But Lord Harewood's not well, so we've come to run the visit and the ball. The door opens and a nanny appears with two boys, aged fo and three. The Princess opens her arms. The boys run to h PRINCESS MARY (CONT’D) Hello, my darlings! How have you been? Have you been having a lovely day? Her face lights up which all the Crawley women notice. INT. KITCHEN/KITCHEN PASSAGE. DOWNTON. DAY. Daisy is working when a young man enters. He’s very hands

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: SELLICK
dialogues.text: This is your lucky day. I'm the new plumber, Tony Sellick.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Right. Well, I'd better show you where the boiler is. She is flustered, as she starts to go, when Andy appears.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Where are you off to?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: This is Mr Sellick, the plumber. I'm taking him to the boiler house.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I’1l do it.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: No, you're all right. Just tell Mrs Patmore where I am. She and Sellick leave. Andy is none too pleased.  30. INT. DRAWING ROOM. HAREWOOD. DAY. They have been served tea. The nanny plays with the boys.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Please bring the boys on Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: Oh, how lovely!

dialogues.speaker: LASCELLES
dialogues.text: Why are the children in here? The Princess' husband has entered the room. The nanny stutters.

dialogues.speaker: HAREWOOD NANNY
dialogues.text: We just got back and they wanted to-

dialogues.speaker: LASCELLES
dialogues.text: They're not allowed in the drawing room before six.

dialogues.speaker: HAREWOOD NANNY
dialogues.text: I know, m'lord. But they-

dialogues.speaker: LASCELLES
dialogues.text: Take them upstairs. And don't bring them down again tonight.

dialogues.speaker: HAREWOOD NANNY
dialogues.text: Yes, m'lord.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: But they were only-

dialogues.speaker: LASCELLES
dialogues.text: Thank you, Nanny. The boys are led out by their nurse.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: You remember Lady Grantham and her daughters?

dialogues.speaker: LASCELLES
dialogues.text: Lady Grantham.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: They want us to bring the boys to the parade.

dialogues.speaker: LASCELLES
dialogues.text: No. They'd only cause a ruckus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were hoping you would both stay for dinner that night, Lord Lascelles.

dialogues.speaker: LASCELLES
dialogues.text: No, I'm afraid not. Well, I'll leave you to it. 31. All of which seems oddly rude. He goes and closes the doo INT. BOILER ROOM. DOWNTON. DAY. Sellick and Daisy survey the boiler.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose I'd better let you get started. So I'll be on my way.

dialogues.speaker: TONY SELLICK
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to wish me luck?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: You don't look as if you need me to wish you luck, Mr Sellick. Or anyone else, for that matter.

dialogues.speaker: TONY SELLICK
dialogues.text: You don't know what I need.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: And I don't intend to find out. He smiles as she goes, blushing at her own boldness. EXT. DOWNTON VILLAGE GREEN. DAY. Bertie and Branson cross the green to look at the finishe dais. All around them the village has been decorated with bunting.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Do we need to cut the grass again?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: They're doing it tomorrow morning. But a man is coming towards him. It is Major

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr Branson. Getting ready for Their Majesties, I see.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: That’s right. This is Lord Hexham. May I present Major Chetwode. Chetwode.  32. Bertie shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Are you here for the parade?

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: I am. I'm staying at the pub.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Bertie goes to talk to the workman. Branson comes closer.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Or are you here to keep an eye on me?

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: I was rather hoping you'd be my guide for the ceremony. Would you like a drink?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I'll join you in a minute. Chetwode walks off towards the King’s Arms.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Who’s he?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I don't really know. Army, perhaps. Or maybe a civil servant. But I'll drink with him and try and put his mind at rest.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: What does he want?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Maybe to make sure I'm a leopard who has changed his spots. EXT. DOWNTON. EVE. The darkening sky is filled with clouds.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What about you, m'lady? Is everything ready? INT. MARY’S BEDROOM. DOWNTON. EVE. Mary is dressing for dinner with Anna’s help.  33.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No. And my heart is pounding. By the way, have you seen the silver box from the table by the fire in the drawing room? My grandmother used to keep playing cards in it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I know the one. Is it missing?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. And so is the little cupid from the mantelshelf. They must have been taken downstairs for cleaning. The door opens and Edith enters, changed.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I was just coming to you, m'lady.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Oh, don't worry. I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: If that's all, m'lady?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I suppose. Can you manage the jug and basin? Or are they too heavy?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No, no. I can do it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How's the boiler?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I'm sure they'll fix it soon. She takes the jug and the china basin and goes.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Bertie was with Tom earlier. Mary looks at her, curious. Edith ploughs on.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don't think Tom would ever... try to make trouble?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Bertie says there's some army type who has him under surveillance.  34.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Tom likes to shock, that's all. He'd never be disloyal to this family. Never. Shall we go down?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Yes, let's. INT. KITCHEN. DOWNTON. NIGHT. Sellick, the plumber and raconteur, is there while dinner being served upstairs. Daisy pours tea for him.

dialogues.speaker: SELLICK
dialogues.text: So I said to her, "Listen, lady, there's a little one here who still needs turning."

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Oh! Careful, Mr Sellick, you'll make Daisy blush.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Takes more than that to make me blush. Now get that down you. But she is smiling up at him as she gives him the tea.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: You deserve that. It's very late.

dialogues.speaker: SELLICK
dialogues.text: Well, I've got to get it done. And I don't mind long hours. I mean to build my own business and you can't do that working nine to five.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: These water jugs nearly killed me. How did we manage in the old days?

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Maybe people were tougher then.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Maybe they expected less from life.

dialogues.speaker: SELLICK
dialogues.text: Well, I expect a lot from life.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: So do I. And I mean to have it, too. He laughs, admiringly.  35.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Are you still here? He is carrying a tray. How long was he watching?

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Mr Sellick's been working hard for hours for our benefit, Andy.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Then it's time he went home. Is the savoury ready?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Take this. Andy collects the tray of savouries and goes.

dialogues.speaker: SELLICK
dialogues.text: He's right. The new pump should arrive around nine. I'll be here.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: So will we.

dialogues.speaker: SELLICK
dialogues.text: Ta-ra! Sellick puts down his cup, walks to the door and leaves. INT. LIBRARY. DOWNTON. NIGHT. Robert pours some whisky as Cora appears.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: That was Mama. She's in London. She's staying with Rosamund.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: She can't be. She was here for lunch. She didn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: She went up this afternoon. She'll be back tomorrow, so I've asked her to come for tea. You must persuade her to leave Maud Bagshaw alone.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I don't believe even Mama will pick a quarrel in front of the King.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: I wonder if he can come early. They laugh.  36.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Are you excited?

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: I am a bit. Are you?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Would it be common to admit it?

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Not to an American. And with that he takes her in his arms and kisses her. EXT./INT. MONTAGE. DOWNTON. DAY. Gardeners trim the grass and rake the paths. Others clean windows. Inside, a frenzy of cleaning. Carson and the hal boys survey the china and crystal. Silver is polished. Ca selects wine from the cellar. Andy winds a clock. EXT. DOWNTON. DAY. Carson, Bates and Mrs Hughes wait as a charabanc halts. A haughty man and a proud woman approach, leading four foot and two maids.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Here we go, Mr Carson.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Leave this to me. The man and woman stop, as if expecting them to stand asi

dialogues.speaker: COURBET
dialogues.text: I am Monsieur Courbet. And this is Mrs Webb, the housekeeper.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Ah. Follow that path and it'll take you into the kitchen courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: COURBET
dialogues.text: I said, I am Monsieur Courbet, chef to Their Majesties. He pushes past them into the hall. Mrs Webb follows.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Well done, Charlie. Always start as you mean to go on.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: This way, gentlemen.  37. INT. DRAWING ROOM/HALL. DOWNTON. DAY. Anna enters to find Miss Lawton. She stops in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Miss Lawton?

dialogues.speaker: LAWTON
dialogues.text: I was just looking round. It's a beautiful house.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You've seen many that are finer. She has been looking for a glove on a side table.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's what I came for. But we shouldn't be in here, really. Lawton leads the way out. INT. KITCHEN. DOWNTON. DAY. The kitchen is chaotic.

dialogues.speaker: COURBET
dialogues.text: You. Where can I put this?

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Don't tempt me.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: We've cleared some space in the scullery. And that cupboard. She rolls her eyes at Mrs Patmore and murmurs.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What a lot of fuss over nothing!

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Where's our order from Mr Bakewell?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Follow me. INT. CUPBOARD. DOWNTON. CONTINUOUS. She leads the way down the crowded passage to a door, pus Mrs Patmore in and turns on a light. The cupboard is pack

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: How did you manage it?  38.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: A gardener helped me carry everything in, so no one saw.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: I suppose you could sell the lot and use the money to pay Mr Bakewell.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Don't worry. They can eat it gradual when the visit's over. INT. KITCHEN PASSAGE. CONTINUOUS. As they emerge, Tony Sellick walks towards them.

dialogues.speaker: SELLICK
dialogues.text: It's done, Mrs Patmore. The new pump's installed.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Hail the conquering hero!

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It's Mrs Hughes you should be telling. Or Mr Carson. Not them.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: It's all right, Mr Sellick. We'll see the news gets through. Thanks. Sellick leaves as Daisy rounds on Andy. They pass Mrs Hug engaged in a row with Mrs Webb.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WEBB
dialogues.text: But I don't need your help, Mrs Hughes. I just want to know where Their Majesties are sleeping so Miss Stinson can prepare the rooms.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Then I will show you, Mrs Webb. Because, without my help, you will not find them. She is livid. INT. BOOT ROOM. DOWNTON. CONTINUOUS. Baxter, Anna and Thomas are with Ellis.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Is it always like this?  39.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: A Royal visit is like a swan on a lake. Grace and serenity above, demented kicking down below.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: I wish I could get away.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: I've got tomorrow night off when Mr Miller arrives. I told my mum I'd look in. Why don't you come to York with me? We could have a drink.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: You should go. You're not on duty.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: That settles it, then. I'll come find you when I'm released. We can borrow a car. Ellis leaves them. By now, a fight has broken out in the passage.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Mrs Webb, I am the housekeeper here. INT. KITCHEN PASSAGE. DOWNTON. CONTINUOUS.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WEBB
dialogues.text: You are not housekeeper so long as His Majesty is under this roof.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: But he's not here yet, is he? INT. HALL. DOWNTON. DAY. Robert, with Teo, walks through the hall as servants scru and clean every surface. INT. LIBRARY. DOWNTON. DAY. Robert, Edith and Bertie join the others for tea. The children are there.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: It's like living in a factory.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It reminds me of our days as a convalescent home during the war.  40.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: I enjoyed that, although I always feel guilty saying so. Where's Tom?

dialogues.speaker: SYBBIE
dialogues.text: Daddy's in the village.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Again? What's he playing at? Nanny steps forward, gathering the children. They leave, passing Violet in the doorway, still in her hat.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I saw Tom looking very stern as I came up the drive.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I hope he's not building a bomb.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Many a true word is spoken in jest. We think he's being tailed by Special Branch.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Nonsense. Mama, how was London?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: What were you there for?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Oh, various things.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But you hate London.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Whoever told you that? Now, when do you want me tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Twelve at the latest. They arrive at half past. But, Mama, you must promise not to attack Maud Bagshaw.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I can't ignore her. She is my cousin.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Exactly. Greet her as a cousin and leave it at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: But even if she has left everything to an outsider, what could we do?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Challenge the will.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: On what basis?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Undue influence.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: But how could you know that? And how would you prove it?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: We'd find a friendly judge.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Friendly or corrupt?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Whichever does the trick.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Are you here for dinner, Mama? It's a buffet.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I'm not changed.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: We won't change either, so you just need to take off your hat.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You talk as if that were easy. Edith scoffs.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Where's the paper knife, the silver one with my regimental crest? At this, Mary looks over sharply. INT. KITCHEN. DOWNTON. EVE. 41. Mrs Patmore is nearly mad. She turns a tap on as she spea  42.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: They won't help tonight, apparently. They won't lift a finger. But then, my food is only fit for servants. Well, at least your young hero seems to have sorted out the water. Daisy laughs as she answers but they have not noticed And

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: He's not my hero.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Yes. Why did you call him that?

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: It was just a joke.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: But why's it funny?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Oh, Andy, leave it. He storms off. Mrs Patmore looks at Daisy but she is unmo EXT. KITCHEN COURTYARD. DOWNTON. EVE. Andy comes out, fuming. He crosses the courtyard. INT. BOILER ROOM. DOWNTON. EVE. Andy looks at the boiler. He picks up a shovel leaning against it and smashes part of the boiler until steam escapes. He drops the shovel. INT. MANSERVANTS’ BEDROOM CORRIDOR. EVE. There’s trouble here too. Thomas watches from a doorway.

dialogues.speaker: COURBET
dialogues.text: But this is a rabbit hutch.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: Don't look at me, Mr Courbet. You couldn't swing a cat in my room.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, please. I'm sure you'll find-  43.

dialogues.speaker: COURBET
dialogues.text: Out of my way! I will have a bath and then I will decide. Perhaps I will find a hotel. He has walked into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: Where can we eat? Somewhere apart?

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Why not in the servants' hall?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: We never eat with the resident staff.

dialogues.speaker: COURBET, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The water's cold. What's happening? He reappears in the bathroom doorway.

dialogues.speaker: COURBET
dialogues.text: This is impossible. We can't stay here with no hot water. Are you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: But the boiler was fixed today. It was hot an hour ago.

dialogues.speaker: COURBET
dialogues.text: Well, it's cold now!

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Why are you here again, Mr Carson? So you could keep control when I would fail? Was that it? I forget.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Mr Barrow, would you mind?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: I'm not on duty, Mr Carson, you are. EXT. DOWNTON. NIGHT. Downton in a torrent of rain. INT. BUTLER’S PANTRY. DOWNTON. NIGHT. Carson enters to find Wilson working at his own desk. Wil decants a bottle of wine.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Since you are in my room, sitting at my desk, it is for me to ask what you want.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Nothing from you.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I would remind you that I have been in charge of Downton for many years.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Mr Carson, you are a retired servant in a minor provincial house, serving an undistinguished family. This is like a physical blow for Carson. WILSON (CONT’D) Your history is of no interest to me. Now, if you will excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: So, what would you like me to do?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: I would like you to find a good book and read it until we leave. Anna appears at the door.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Mr Carson, you'd better come and see this. She goes and Carson follows, bruised. INT. KITCHEN PASSAGE. DOWNTON. NIGHT. Sellick is with Mrs Patmore and Daisy. Andy sees them fro the passage.

dialogues.speaker: SELLICK
dialogues.text: It's well and truly damaged.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Can you mend it in time?  45.

dialogues.speaker: SELLICK
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. But somebody should tell them someone wanted to wreck the Royal visit. They ought to know. INT. DINING ROOM. DOWNTON. NIGHT. They help themselves from a buffet laid on the sideboard, then sit at the table. Cora turns to Edith as Carson ente

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Has the dress arrived?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Not yet. What am I going to wear?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Carson, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Some folding chairs-- Well, a great many chairs have been delivered, m'lady. They're at the back door. Anna thought you should be told at once.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: She's right. They're for the parade. We'll have to set them out tonight, there'll be no time tomorrow. The villagers will start arriving from nine onwards. She hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: MERTON
dialogues.text: I'm not sure fate is on our side.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Poor little Mary. Have we let her take on too much?

dialogues.speaker: MERTON
dialogues.text: You're right. Come on. We should lend her a hand.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: You can't go out in this.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Of course we can. Good night, Mama. Remember to pray for us, mainly for better weather.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I'll put in a word.  46. He hurries away with Merton. VIOLET (CONT’D) Of course, little Mary could hammer in a tent peg with her teeth.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: I wonder who she got that from.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You know, I'm always surprised when you praise me.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: I'm surprised to hear that I have. INT. KITCHEN PASSAGE. DOWNTON. NIGHT. Outside the kitchen Mary’s with Anna, in the passage. We hear the heavy rain.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: As if things aren't bad enough without a thunderstorm.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: We'll manage. I've roped in Mr Molesley, and Andy's gone for the truck. But Mr Bates can't help and Mr Barrow has vanished.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Ditto. Lord Hexham's out looking for Mr Branson. We'll have to do our best without them.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You're not going yourself?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How else will they know what to do?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Then I'll fetch our coats.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You don't have to come.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Of course I do. I'll just tell Mr Bates where I've gone.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You're a good friend to me, Anna.  47.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I hope we're good friends to each other, m'lady. She hurries off. For once, Mary is quite moved by this. EXT. KITCHEN COURTYARD. DOWNTON. NIGHT. Andy and Molesley are loading the chairs into a truck wit Mary and Anna, when Robert and Merton come hurrying up.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Here we are. All set and ready.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh, Papa, Dickie, you're so kind. But are you sure? You'll be soaked to the skin and filthy.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What's that to us? We're hunting men. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: MERTON
dialogues.text: You don't need to come, my dear. We can manage it between us.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Of course I'm coming. Come along.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Cheer up, Molesley. EXT./INT. KING’S ARMS. DOWNTON VILLAGE. NIGHT. Through the pub window, in the rain, Branson and Chetwode talking over their pints of beer.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: The villagers and guests will watch from both sides of the dais. And there'll be seats at the front kept for the family. They sit near the fire.

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: I'll join you there.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I suppose so.

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: We'll meet in the high street where we planned. Don't bring anyone. Come on your own.  48. He smiles. Naturally,

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's all ridiculous, of course. It's a lot of fuss over nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: What? I thought you were here to check I didn't do anything foolish and spoil things.

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: In what way?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I don't know. Throw eggs or wave a banner or shout.

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: Will you?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: No. But I'm starting to wonder about you. he’s joking, but Chetwode returns his stare.

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: I don't throw eggs. Have another?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Yes. He stands to buy the drinks, leaving Branson with an opaq expression that is hard to read.

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: Same again, please. EXT. DOWNTON VILLAGE GREEN. NIGHT. In lashing rain, Molesley, Andy, Robert, Merton, Mary and Anna carry folded seats towards the dais. Mary counts.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: We'll bring a special chair up for the Queen after breakfast when, hopefully, it will have stopped raining.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: I shall carry it myself, m'lord!

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What about the King?

dialogues.speaker: MERTON
dialogues.text: He'll be on his horse.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: But suppose it's still raining?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: God will make it stop. Across the green, Branson is leaving the pub.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Is that Tom? Has he been in the pub the whole evening? Huh. Mary stares at Branson.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOWNTON. DAY
dialogues.text: Downton on a beautiful, sunny day. Mary stands near Carson. The servants stand in a line.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well, the day has dawned and the weather proves conclusively that God is a Monarchist.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Who could doubt it, m'lady? Robert comes out with Bertie, Branson, Edith, Violet and Mertons, the men all in tweeds.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Here they come now. She’s right. The two gleaming cars are progressing up the drive. The first car stops beside them. The doors are hel open and King George V and Queen Mary get out. Molesley starts to hyper-ventilate.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Mr Molesley?

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: I'm all right. I just need a moment to catch my breath. Cora plunges into a deep court curtsey before the King an Queen.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Your Majesties, welcome to Downton Abbey.  50.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: We're glad to be here, Lady Grantham. Grantham. Robert gives a sharp neck bow. Cora takes over.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: You remember Lord Grantham's mother. Violet curtsies deeply. The King gives her his hand.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hello, Lady Grantham. Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Someone must, sir, or I may never rise again. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: My daughter, Lady Mary Talbot, The Marquess and Marchioness of Hexham, Mr Tom Branson. Branson gives a very slight neck bow. Mary sighs with rel She looks at Bertie. CORA (CONT’D) Lord and Lady Merton. The Queen is being led down the same line by Robert.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: This is kind of you, Lord Grantham.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Not at all. It is a great honour. I'm sure you know, but Princess Mary and Lord Lascelles will be joining us for luncheon and the parade.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: They're both coming?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: As far as I'm aware.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: What a relief. Please forget I said that.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Said what, ma'am?  51. She squeezes his arm. The others have curtsied and bowed. Robert gestures to the servants. Behind them walks Bagshaw. She and Violet will be equally matched. They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Cousin Maud.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Violet.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Are we going to kiss?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I'm glad you want to kiss me. It wasn't quite what you said when I last heard from you.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: It wasn't quite how I felt when I wrote. EXT. KITCHEN COURTYARD. DOWNTON. DAY. Lady Branson is loitering outside when he sees a young woman arrive, struggling with two cases. He walks towards her.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Can I help you at all?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Thanks. The others all shot off, and I'm not sure if this is the right way.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: If you just come with me. What's your part in this circus?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I'm Lady Bagshaw's maid.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Oh well, then it's this door. If you just ask for Mrs Hughes. She'll look after you.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Thank you. They have reached the back door. He watches her go in.  52. INT. KITCHEN PASSAGE. DOWNTON. DAY. Lucy walks past the others as Albert gives a bandbox to A

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: This has just arrived for Lady Edith.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Lady Hexham these days, Mr Bates. But-- Thank you, Albert. It's a relief. She starts up the servants’ staircase. INT. KITCHEN. DOWNTON. DAY. Courbet is in his chef’s toque and screaming at his minio

dialogues.speaker: COURBET
dialogues.text: I want the milk now! I want the egg yolks now! I want the olive oil now! And I want the vanilla pod now!

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: He wants a clip round the ear now.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Careful, Mrs Patmore. Right. Who's taking this up? Mr Molesley? Molesley, in day livery, lifts the serving plate as Anna enters with Bates. Wilson pushes forward.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: There's no need for you to meddle, Mrs Hughes. We will see to it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Meddle? I don't believe I'm meddling in my own house, thank you. Andrew, yes. You take that one.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: But it's not your house, is it? So would you like to go and sit down?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Now, just a minute. He is infuriated by what he is witnessing. Molesley has carried his plate out of the room. So has Andy.  53.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: You! Leave those! Put them down. For heaven's sake, go after them! Two Royal footmen race out. Carson has seen the end of th

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I really must protest. My staff are-

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Keep them down here, Mr Carson. That goes for you too. Stay out of our way! You've seen Their Majesties. Let it be enough. Wilson has gone, leaving them all dumb struck. INT. SERVERY. DOWNTON. DAY. Andy and Molesley prepare their plates, but the Royal foo snatch the dishes out of their hands.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. What are you playing at? The footmen carry the plates out of the servery. Andy sco INT. DINING ROOM. DOWNTON. DAY. As the footmen enter, the King and Queen sit opposite eac other. Violet is on the King’s left. The King is talking Cora on his right.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: Things seem calmer in the north.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: You mean after the strike, sir? Yes, if calmer means more resigned. I'm not sure what the future holds. The King looks towards Violet.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: And you, Lady Grantham? Were you affected by the general strike?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: My maid was rather curt with me while it was on, Sir. But she is a communist at heart so I suppose it was only to be expected.  54. Robert is sitting on the Queen’s right.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: Wasn't the Princess joining us?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: They telephoned. Lord Lascelles has been held up by something. But they are planning to come for the parade. The Queen raises her eyebrows slightly. Down the table Ma Bagshaw is on Branson's left. Edith on Branson’s right.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I imagine the servants' bedrooms are quite pleasant here.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Why? Are you worried for your maid?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: How clever of you. Lucy is more of a companion than a maid. I'd hate for her to be uncomfortable. Branson is getting restless.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Of course. He turns to Edith.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I really have to go.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: You can't embarrass Mama. I'm sorry, but you must wait until we stand. Branson snatches up the menu holder, reads it and groans.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: Lord Hexham, how is Northumberland?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: As beautiful as ever, sir.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: Can it spare you, do you think? Edith glances at her husband.  55. INT. KITCHEN PASSAGE/SERVANTS’ HALL. DOWNTON. DAY. Molesley and Andy hurry down the stairs and head into the hall. Mrs Patmore, Carson, Bates, Anna, Mrs Hughes and Da are in a huddle.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: We might as well all go for a walk.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: We cannot challenge the way a Royal visit is conducted, Mrs Patmore.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I'm not so sure.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Why don't we all meet back here after the parade?

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Anna, Mr Bates, there must be no trouble or disloyal tomfoolery of any kind. Do you hear me? He strides away. The others share the moment.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: We'll meet in the wine cellar. Tell the others. Now, I'm walking to Mr Bakewell's, if you've any errands. Mrs Patmore shakes her head. INT. DINING ROOM/HALL. DOWNTON. DAY. Luncheon is over. The equerry catches the King’s eye.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: We should get moving. He stands and they all rise to their feet. He leads the w out.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: What was the King saying earlier? I couldn't hear.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: He's planning a tour for the Prince of Wales next March. It'll take in most of the African colonies and finish in Cape Town.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: And he wants you to go?  56.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: He thinks I'm a steadying influence.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: How long would you be away?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: About three months. I can't believe my luck. Can you? INT. HALL. DOWNTON. DAY. In the hall, Branson hurries off, watched by Mary. EXT. DOWNTON VILLAGE. MAIN STREET. DAY. The mounted squadron moves forward, down the main street, towards the green. As they pass they reveal Branson approaching the pub. He does not see Mary following him. INT. A ROOM AT THE KING’S ARMS. DOWNTON VILLAGE. DAY. Chetwode takes a revolver out of a drawer. He checks that it’s loaded and puts it in his inside coat pocket. EXT. DOWNTON VILLAGE. MAIN STREET. DAY. Chetwode comes out of the pub. Branson is walking towards as Mary arrives.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Tom!

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: What on earth are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I might ask you the same question.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Go back or you'll ruin things.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Isn't that what you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: You don't know what I'm doing. Chetwode has walked over to them so Branson cannot explai The crowd continues to cheer as the troops pass.

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: Who's this?  57.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: This is my sister-in-law, Lady Mary Talbot.

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: I told you to come alone. With a glance at Mary, he hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Leave this to me. He runs off. Mary follows him. Chetwode disappears into the crowd, turns and runs across street between mounted horses and gun carriages. Branson in pursuit, but he cannot cross as the street is now fill with cavalry. Chetwode ducks into a side alley and then i an empty barn. Branson dodges the horses and gives chase, followed by Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chetwode emerges from the barn to see the King on horseba with his equerry in front of him. They are walking slowly towards the parade and don’t see Chetwode emerge. He lift his gun to take aim, when Branson slams him to the ground as they struggle.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Tom!

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Get the gun! Mary steps on the wrist with the gun, forcing Chetwode to go. She kicks the gun away. Two plain clothed officers ar at the run and pull Chetwode up, leading him away. Branso gets up. EXT. DOWNTON VILLAGE. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Are you all right, sir? Your Ladyship?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Why are you even here? I didn't suspect him myself until last night. Branson shakes his head. So does Mary. As Chetwode is cuf his anger takes over.  58.

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: How was I to know you'd given up on a free Ireland?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Isn’t it free now?

dialogues.speaker: CHETWODE
dialogues.text: Not with the bloody Crown around its neck! They watch him bundled into a police car.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I'm not impressed you all decided I was a Royal assassin.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I didn't. It was really the others. Branson’s expression rather questions this.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: If you'll follow us to the station. They nod and set off after the police van.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell us?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I thought he'd come to check up on me and didn't want to drag you into it. I assumed he'd back off if I answered his questions and met him for a drink. But last night at the pub, I realised he wanted to use me to get close to the King. EXT. DOWNTON VILLAGE GREEN. DAY. Everyone stands as the King rides on to the parade ground attended by his equerry and other mounted officers. The national anthem strikes up. Anna creeps up to Mrs Patmore and Daisy. Bates is there. nods at him.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Sorry. Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: We thought you'd miss it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I was just in time.  59.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I don't know why I bothered.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Shh! The commanding officer rides up to the King, salutes with sword and asks:

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDING OFFICER
dialogues.text: Your Majesty, The Yorkshire Hussars are formed up, ready and awaiting your inspection. Escorted by the commanding officer, the King rides to the right of the line, accompanied by the escorting officers. band plays as the inspection begins. The Queen has notice empty chair next to her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: He's not feeling well.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: Wasn't he out shooting yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: What do you want me to say?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: You have to let me leave him.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: We will not talk about it now. Cora turns to the Princess. Further down, Maud waves at L in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Is that your maid?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: That’s right. Lucy.
