dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Don't you call her by her surname?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: She's been with me so long. This troubles Violet which Edith registers. In the backgr the magnificent parade is still in full swing.  60. EXT. THE VILLAGE POLICE STATION. DAY. Mary and Branson come out and start walking up the street

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It's so strange. He seemed so English.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: And so he was. A pillar of the establishment until the notion of Irish independence took him over to the other side. That's where I came in. He'd heard my sympathies lay with Ireland and the republic.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Don't they?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Not at any cost. I'm a law-and- order man these days. That's what you lot have done to me.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So will there be a great splash all over the newspapers? Poor Papa.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Oh, no. You'll find there isn't a whisper about this anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: An establishment cover-up. I don't believe in conspiracy theories. But he just smiles and they walk on. EXT. DOWNTON VILLAGE GREEN. DAY. The crowd disperses. Lucy Smith is also leaving. Branson quickens his pace. Edith, with Bertie and others, notices

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Ah, Miss Smith. Did Mrs Hughes sort you out?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: She did.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: And have you enjoyed the parade? They laugh. She gives him a glance but he smiles and so d she.  61.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Do you work at the house?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Not exactly. I sell cars and I help with the estate. Lord Grantham is my father-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Oh, I do beg your pardon, sir. She starts to drop back but he slows for her to join him.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: No, please, let me explain. I started here as the chauffeur.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: You must be Lady Sybil's husband.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Lady Bagshaw and I followed the story. We were so sad when she died. How long ago was it?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Seven years, or nearly. My God.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. It's still painful.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Not in that way. It doesn't hurt anymore, but it's still there.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Was it hard, coming up like that? Joining the family. He looks at her. Then he decides to answer her question.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Very hard. Between my old world and the new one, sometimes I didn't know who I was.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: But you do now?  62.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I think so, yes. I came to terms with it. Why?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I'm just curious. Once again, Edith is watching them. INT. THE WINE CELLAR. DOWNTON. DAY. The Downton servants are in the wine cellar. Anna is ushe them along. Baxter and Barrow are the last to enter.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Can somebody tell me what's going on? Anna?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Shh!

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: What are we all doing down here? Bates locks the door and turns to face the others.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: This is most improper.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Yes, why have you got us all here?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I will tell you. Mr Bates and I, we want to defend Downton's honour.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: In what way?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Would you like a repeat of how you were all treated at luncheon?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: No, I bloody well would not.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Andrew! There are ladies present.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: We think we should fight back.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I don't like the sound of this. I do not like this at all.  63.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Anna, tell them.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: We are going to clear the way so you cook and serve dinner for the King and Queen at Downton Abbey. As you should.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! Is this a revolution?

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: Shall I fetch the pitchforks?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: We're serious, Mr Molesley.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: But do you know what Mr Courbet has brought in for tonight?

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Never mind that. We've got our own supplies.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: And you can leave Mr Courbet to me.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: What do you want us to do?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Don't bother with the maids and valets. We've no quarrel with them.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: But we need to get rid of the Royal butler for the night.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: The Page of the Backstairs, if you don't mind, Mr Bates. He is loving it. Bates is more serious.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: And the footmen need to be out of commission from seven until you finish serving.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: This is treason!

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: What can we do about them?  64.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: We could lock them in the attic.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Any more talk like that and we'll all end up in Botany Bay.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: And did you enjoy being pushed around and passed over and told to stay down here by Mr Wilson? She has been silent until now. Carson is caught. In agony

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I will play no active part in this. Suppose His Majesty sees what's going on and is displeased?

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Why? Do you think I'm not capable of cooking a decent dinner?

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Oh, no, of course not. But I-

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: I'll see to the footmen.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: You'll find out.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: So, does this mean we're back on duty after all? Me and Mr Molesley?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: And Albert as well. You know where to find the state liveries.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: Will I pour wine for the Queen's sweet lips?

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Any more of that and we'll lock you in the attic.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I don't know why you're bothering.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: What about that Mrs Webb who keeps telling us she's the housekeeper?  65.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Don't you worry about Mrs Webb. I am more than a match for Mrs Webb. INT. KITCHEN PASSAGE. DAY. By the cellar door, they are dispersing.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I still don't know how you're going to manage Mr Courbet.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Well, there’s-- At that moment Courbet appears, yawning.

dialogues.speaker: COURBET
dialogues.text: I'm just going upstairs to lie down. Can you get things ready for when I come back?

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: And when will that be, Oh Mighty One? He does not like her tone, but he decides not to quarrel.

dialogues.speaker: COURBET
dialogues.text: Wake me in half an hour if I'm not already in the kitchen. But he is stifled by his yawns as he sets off for the sta They are all amazed. The others stare at Anna. Bates smil

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Trust us. INT. HALL. DOWNTON. DAY. The King and Queen, the family, Maud Bagshaw and the Mert are having tea. Other guests, who came to watch the parad have joined them. They are served by the four Royal footm Mary is with Violet, Maud, Merton and Isobel.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Tell us about your maid.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Lucy is the daughter of David's army servant, Jack Smith. And, like my husband, he died in the Boer Wars.

dialogues.speaker: MERTON
dialogues.text: So you looked after his child?  66.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Lucy had no mother, you see. So I gave her a home.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: That's very generous.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Generosity that has been amply returned, I can assure you.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m glad.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You don't sound very glad. EXT. GARDENS. DOWNTON. DAY. Branson, now in a morning coat, is watching Sybbie and th others play. Nanny waits nearby. There is movement in the shadows and Branson investigates. Princess Mary is crying She sits on a bench. Branson clears his throat to announc his presence.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: Goodness. I thought everyone was in the drawing room. She looks at him and wipes her eyes briskly.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I've been dodging it, I'm afraid. I suppose I ought to get back. Can I get someone for you?

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: No. Thank you. You're the widower of the youngest daughter, aren't you? I've heard of you, Mr...

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Branson. Tom Branson. And who are you? I should know, but I'm no good at that sort of thing. After a puzzled moment, this pleases her.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: I suppose you can't be expected to know everyone. Did you enjoy the parade?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I missed it completely. I got distracted.  67.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: What a shame.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Well, to be honest, I'm not much of a Royalist. Although, I probably shouldn't say that out loud.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: Certainly not to a stranger. That seems odd as the Crawleys would die for the Crown if they had to.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: You can love people you disagree with.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: And you love them?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: They're decent at the core.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: People can be decent at the core but very difficult to live with.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: True enough. They're silly too and snobbish at times. And I wouldn't give tuppence for their politics. But I've learned to be happy with all of that. And, besides, they're my daughter's family. She looks over to where the children are playing.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: And she lives here?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I nearly took her away once. She belongs here now. I spent so much of my life not belonging anywhere. That's important to me.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: I suppose, in the end, it's deciding what's important, isn't it? You've given me a great deal to think about, Mr Branson.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Good things, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: That may be so, but now we must go in.  68. They get up. INT. HALL. DOWNTON. DAY. Violet is now with Maud and Isobel.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: We must change. And you leave in the morning. I wonder if we might have a talk later? We'll finda cosy spot. And Robert can join us.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I won't be interrogated, Violet.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Please, don't miss the chance to settle things between you. She glances at Violet. Maud looks at them both for a mome

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Very well. But now I must go. She joins the Queen and Their Majesties lead the way out.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: That was helpful. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: I told you I wanted to help.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Well, thanks to you, we have her cornered. She leaves. Isobel is not entirely sure she is pleased. INT. KITCHEN PASSAGE. DOWNTON. DAY. Wilson is walking past. Bates and Baxter are waiting.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: Mr Wilson, there's a telephone call for you.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: For me? INT. BUTLER’S PANTRY. DOWNTON. DAY. Wilson, talking on the telephone, is bewildered.  69.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: But, Sir Harry, they wouldn't get to London until nine.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS, (OVER TELEPHONE)
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. The ball at Clarence House won't start ‘til ten.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: What ball at Clarence House?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS, (OVER TELEPHONE)
dialogues.text: The Duke of Connaught's. What are you playing at, Wilson?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: I'm not questioning you, sir. Not if it's what the Duke of Connaught wishes. But how do I manage here?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS, (OVER TELEPHONE)
dialogues.text: Don't they have footmen at Downton?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Yes. There are footmen. But won't His Majesty--

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS, (OVER TELEPHONE)
dialogues.text: His Majesty won't give a tinker's cuss. Now do as I say!

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Of course, Sir Harry, at once. He puts down the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: INT. POST OFFICE. DOWNTON VILLAGE. DAY
dialogues.text: Ellis hangs up the telephone. He and Thomas stifle laughs INT. BUTLER’S PANTRY. DOWNTON. DAY Bates and Baxter are watching.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Everything all right, Mr Wilson?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: I need to see my footmen, and the house footmen and the hall boy. When is the next train to London?

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: I hope it's not bad news.  70.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Not bad, exactly, but irregular. Very irregular indeed. EXT. POST OFFICE. DOWNTON VILLAGE. DAY. Thomas and Ellis leave the post office. They are in stitc

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: I'll get drummed out of the regiment if they ever find out.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: You sounded convincing to me.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: I'm very good at doing Sir Harry Barnston, I can assure you.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: What if Mr Wilson rings back?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: No one queries Sir Harry's orders.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: But if he did?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: Then they'd uncover the trick. But they couldn't trace it back to me. Right. Shall we go into York?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to miss out on the fun in a way. Where shall I wait for you when you're with your parents?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: We'll find a pub. INT. EDITH’S BEDROOM. DOWNTON. DAY. Edith is wearing her new ball dress. It is huge. Prettily embroidered but huge. Anna comes in.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Did you manage to speak to someone?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I got hold of Madame Seymour's assistant. They've sent you the wrong one. It's similar in style, but not, as you can see, in size.  71.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Where's my dress now?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: On its way to New York.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Well, that's that, then. Wonderful. Everything's going wrong for me today.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: M’ lady?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Never mind. How are things downstairs? Any better? Anna helps Edith out of the dress and into a dressing gow

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: A bit better. Yes, m'lady. In fact, I ought to be getting back.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Of course. One thing. The painted glass that used to sit by my bed, was it broken while I was away?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Leave it with me, m'lady, and the dress. You wouldn't mind a fitting later tonight, would you?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I don't understand. Who with?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’ve just had an idea. INT. MAUD BAGSHAW’S BEDROOM. DOWNTON. EVE. Violet opens the door. Maud sits at the dressing table. H maid, Lucy, stands beside her. Both are chuckling.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I shouldn't think so, not if she knows what's good for her. They peal with laughter again. Now Violet speaks.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to interrupt. Maud swings round, her eyes narrow.  72.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: How clever of you to find me.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Not really. I lived here forty years. I assume this is your maid.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Yes. This is Lucy Smith.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Oh, good evening, Smith.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Good evening, m'lady. Shall I go?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Not for me. Not for me. I'm delighted to meet you. I've heard so much about you.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Is there something you want?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Just to see you're comfortable, and to confirm our little chat for later.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I live my own life now, Violet. I'm not what I was. My father is gone. My husband is gone. I see no reason not to do what I want.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: That doesn't mean there is no reason, merely that you cannot see it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I think Lady Merton is right. We'll have it out, once and for all. But now I must go to Her Majesty. She puts on her gloves and leaves. Violet stares at Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Hmm. Violet turns and goes. INT. KITCHEN. DOWNTON. EVE. Wilson lectures Molesley, Andy and the hall boys, in stat livery. Baxter, Bates, Anna, Mrs Patmore, Mrs Hughes and Daisy listen  73.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: You're not to speak. You're not to think. Just follow my lead. Their Majesties must not know they're being served by anyone different. Do you hear me? I don't want them to even notice.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: We will do our best, Mr Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: I don't want your best. I want far better than your best.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Is everything under control here, Mr Wilson? I gather the others caught the train.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: And this is what we're left with.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Mind you don't disgrace the state livery, Albert.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT THE HALL BOY
dialogues.text: Of course, Mr Carson.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Where is Monsieur Courbet? I came in here to see him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: He went out. So I thought I'd better get on with dinner. Wasn't I right?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: No. You were not right. You were entirely WRONG!

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Oh! Mrs Patmore has contrived to spill the bowl of sauce she stirring down the front of Wilson’s livery. He is furious MRS PATMORE (CONT’D) Oh, I'm sorry. I don't know how that happened.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: I shall have to go and change. We'll sort this out when I return. He walks off.  74.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (WHISPERS)
dialogues.text: Andy. Andy nods and leaves. INT. EDITH’S BEDROOM. DOWNTON. EVE. Edith is filling an evening bag.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: If you don't want me to, I won't.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: But you've already said that you will.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Because it's a fantastic chance. It didn't occur to me you'd mind.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I don't exactly, not in that way.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Then in what way?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I wasn't going to tell you. I wasn't going to tell anyone. But... He waits for her explanation.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I might be pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Oh, darling. How marvellous. How fabulous. My heart is bursting. They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Well, that's exactly what I don't want. It could easily go wrong.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: But, if it doesn't-

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Then I'll give birth just as you set off on your three-month colonial tour.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Why didn't you say this when I first mentioned it?  75.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: You'd agreed before I had the chance.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Secrets always muddle things.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. That's right. Let's make it my fault.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Well, I'll tell the King I can't go.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: And he'll accept that, will he? INT. MANSERVANTS’ BEDROOM CORRIDOR/WILSON’S BEDROOM/ COURBET’S BEDROOM. EVE. Andy walks down the passage holding a keyring. Wilson is changing his shirt. Outside, Andy turns the key silently the lock. Then he removes it. He walks down the passage a locks the door to Courbet’s room. Courbet is fast asleep. INT. BEDROOM GALLERY. DOWNTON. EVE. Edith and Mary emerge, just as Lucy leaves Maud’s room.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Hello. It's Miss Smith, isn't it? We were talking about you earlier. Weren't we? Mary looks at her, puzzled. Branson, in white tie, appear

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, Tom. What luck! You know Miss Smith, don't you? Come along, Mary. She hurries away with a bewildered Mary.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Are you all right? Has something happened?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Old Lady Grantham came in while we were dressing. I think the stage is set for a fight later, about me. She thinks Lady Bagshaw means to favour me and she doesn't approve.  76.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: What business is it of hers? Lady Bagshaw must have her reasons. And that's good enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Going down, Tom? He has emerged from his dressing room. The two men walk o

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Good night. INT. SERVANTS' HALL. DOWNTON. NIGHT. Miss Lawton is sewing when Anna looks in.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: There you are, Miss Lawton. I hope you're having a well-earned rest.

dialogues.speaker: LAWTON
dialogues.text: There's always less for me to do when Miss Aplin arrives. But we must be ready for the ball tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: That's what I want to talk about. Later this evening, when I go up to help Lady Hexham, I want you to come with me, fit a new ball dress and sew it overnight so it's done before you leave in the morning. Miss Lawton stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: LAWTON
dialogues.text: Why on earth would I do that?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: The box and cupid from the drawing room, the library paper knife, Lady Hexham's painted glass? The penny drops painfully.

dialogues.speaker: LAWTON
dialogues.text: I never took the glass.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Then it must have been broken, like she said. But you took something from that room. What was it?  77.

dialogues.speaker: LAWTON
dialogues.text: A patch box from the dressing table.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I'd like them all back, please.

dialogues.speaker: LAWTON
dialogues.text: I can't sew a dress in a night. When would I sleep?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: When you get to Harewood tomorrow. And don't think I won't tell. "Queen's dresser a thief". That'll make headlines from here to Peru. Anna leaves. EXT. DOWNTON ABBEY. NIGHT. The guests are arriving for the dinner. The men wear cour dress with decorations, the women glimmer in tiaras. INT. HALL. DOWNTON. NIGHT. The King and Queen, with Cora and Robert, are receiving.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: The Marquess and Marchioness of Granby. Sir William and Lady Ingleby. Mary moves to Molesley’s side.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Where are the Royal footmen?

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: They've had to go back to London.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: All of them? Wasn't that rather unlucky?

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: Unlucky for some, m'lady. George, Sybbie, Marigold and Johnnie are watching from th gallery with their nanny, laughing and pointing down at t gleaming, glamorous throng below. Mary blows them a kiss. INT. WILSON’S BEDROOM/MANSERVANTS’ BEDROOM CORRIDOR. EVE. Wilson is wrestling with the bedroom door.  78.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: For goodness' sake! Help me. Will someone help me? But in the empty passage, no one is listening. INT. PUBLIC HOUSE. YORK. NIGHT. Thomas is waiting. It has clearly been a long time. A man the bar is giving him the eye. He nods towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: WEBSTER
dialogues.text: I'm going on to Turton's ina minute. Do you know it? I'm Chris Webster, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for someone.

dialogues.speaker: WEBSTER
dialogues.text: For a very long time. Perhaps he's found better things to do.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: WEBSTER
dialogues.text: Why don't you come with me? You know you want to. Thomas stares at him. He sups some beer and puts down the glass.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir? My name's Barrow. If someone comes looking for me, could you tell him I've gone?

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: Shall I say where to? Thomas and Webster speak simultaneously.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS WEBSTER
dialogues.text: Turton's. Never mind that. They go. The barman watches them as they walk out. INT. SERVERY. DOWNTON. EVE. Bates, Andy, Molesley, the boys and Mrs Hughes are busy w preparations. Carson enters in tails and breeches.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I just cannot understand where Mr Wilson has got to.  79.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Never mind him. What about you? Surely you can't really mean to leave His Majesty unattended.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: But is it for me to attend him?

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Well, you've got your breeches on.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I have, but-

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Mr Carson, this is your destiny. You know as much, and so do I. Now accept it proudly. And walk into that room with your head held high.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: You can do it, Mr Carson. Carson pauses, thinks, nods and heads to the dining room. Webb comes in. She is furious.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WEBB
dialogues.text: Please tell me what is going on!

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Mr Courbet is missing, ditto Mr Wilson, and your footmen are on their way up to London.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WEBB
dialogues.text: I am still in charge here.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: No, Mrs Webb. These are my people now. So please, go back to the servants' hall and sit down. Or would you rather ruin the evening?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: That's telling her. Mrs Webb might protest but thinks better and retreats as and Baxter arrive, carrying sauce boats and bowls.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Mrs Patmore forgot to send up the sauce.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: And I've got the chopped egg.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: That's kind when it's not your job.  80.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Nonsense. We must all pull our weight tonight for Downton's glory.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Now, are you ready, boys?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT THE HALL BOY
dialogues.text: Ready as we'll ever be.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: We'll be fine, Mrs Hughes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: What about you, Mr Molesley?

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: I know I'm going to forget my lines.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: You haven't got any lines!

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You're on.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: Oh, right.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: And Mr Molesley? Remember to breathe.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: Breathe. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. INT. DINING ROOM/SERVERY. DOWNTON. EVE. The dining room and the company make a splendid impressio Molesley floats in, moving behind the Queen as Andy goes the King. Albert follows with a serving plate. Andy stands beside Carson. He whispers.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I'm glad you're here, Mr Carson.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I must go where my king needs me. He himself walks like an emperor.  81. EXT. TURTON’S. YORK. NIGHT Thomas and Webster approach a closed door. Webster knocks a rhythmic pattern. A security guard opens the door. INT. TURTON’S. YORK. NIGHT. Thomas enters the bar with Chris Webster. He looks round, amazed. It is a covert gay club. Men are dancing with men TURTON’S PATRON Looks like we’ve got some new blood here. Hello.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: I can't believe this. I've never seen anything like it.

dialogues.speaker: WEBSTER
dialogues.text: There's a first time for everything.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: I know, but...

dialogues.speaker: WEBSTER
dialogues.text: Come dance with me. Webster takes Thomas’ hand and leads him through the club INT. DINING ROOM. DOWNTON. NIGHT. The dinner guests enjoy their meal.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I wish I could tell them how grateful they should be to you.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: You were every bit as brave as I was.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Mary, you're talking in the wrong direction. The other women have followed the Queen to face the other way. Except Mary. She turns. Now Branson is talking to Ed

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Don't worry about Granny. She's getting ready to give Cousin Maud a grilling. Mainly, I suspect, about her maid.  This isa 82.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I think Lady Bagshaw sees her as more than just her maid.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I'm sure she does. And that's what Granny's afraid of.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I might as well admit... I like her.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Good. Don't let them put you off. surprise and Branson turns to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Tom, you're looking pleased with yourself.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: He was just praising Lady Bagshaw's maid.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: How did she contrive to make your acquaintance?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: She didn't contrive anything. We met by chance.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What simpletons men are. The King speaks to Cora on his right.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: This is good. And I thought something else was planned. But it is excellent. So, a well done to old Courbet.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: Oh, this wasn't Monsieur Courbet, Your Majesty. Mrs Patmore cooked it. In fact, it is the Downton Abbey staff who are serving you this evening. This silences the room. Andy makes a horrified face at Molesley who suddenly realises he’s broken every sacred l

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I do beg your pardon, Your Majesty.  83.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: That's quite enough, Molesley. Molesley is trembling with nerves and humiliation. He is literally paralysed. The Queen decides to save the moment

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: You must give our compliments to Mrs Patmore and to all the staff.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Molesley, Her Majesty is speaking to you. Molesley had been locked in a mist of dark, satanic horro but now the sun breaks through. He opens, like a flower.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: With pleasure, Your Majesty He plunges into a cross between a bow and a curtsey and slowly backs out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: That was kind of you, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: I suppose he's excited that they've had to take over from our people. I wonder what's happened.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Whatever may have happened does not excuse his behaviour.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: I can assure you, Lady Grantham, we are quite used to people behaving strangely when we are near. Which makes Cora laugh. INT. TURTON’S. YORK. NIGHT. Thomas is very drunk. He is also dancing the tango with Webster. He has never had such a good time. Until the air rent with the sound of a loud whistle. The band stops. A policeman in uniform is facing them. EXT. TURTON’S. YORK. NIGHT Black Marias are parked in the road. Policemen run toward the club.  84.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TURTON'S. YORK. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Policemen surround the men in the club.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: All right, gentlemen. That's the end of your evening. Shut that music up now! Right! You are all coming to the station with us.

dialogues.speaker: WEBSTER
dialogues.text: We're just having a bit of fun, Officer. No one's making any trouble.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: That's for the judge to decide.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Judge?

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: What did you think? We were going to slap your wrists and send you home?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: I've never been here before.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Well, you're here now. Right! Gather your things. You're coming with us, you dirty perverts. EXT. TURTON’S. YORK. NIGHT. The club is in a dark side street. The men are loaded in the Black Marias, Thomas among them. On the other side of road Ellis is watching from the car. INT. LIBRARY. DOWNTON. NIGHT. Supervised by Carson, Molesley and Andy dispense coffee a drinks. Violet is with Isobel. She drops her voice.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I met the maid. She has Maud wound around her little finger.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Then we need to know why. Bertie approaches the King, who turns to him, smiling.  85.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: What is it, Hexham?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Well, Your Majesty, it's this. I've just learned that Lady Hexham is expecting our first child.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: But that's wonderful news.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: We're not telling anyone quite yet. But I thought you'd be interested.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: And so I am. Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: The thing is, Sir, it's due to be born around the time the Prince and I will be setting off on tour.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: Excellent! Please make it register with him. Help the Prince to understand what it means to have a real family life. You can be such an example to him, I know it. Bertie drops back, stumped. Maud, Violet, Cora, Robert an Isobel are sitting together.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Very well. Let's get to the point. Robert is my nearest relation on my father's side.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: He is.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: But he will not be my heir.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: And there we have it.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Who will be? Can you tell us?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Lucy Smith, my maid. This does not come as a surprise to Isobel. It does to Co

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What? Are you out of your mind?  86.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: No. And I know what I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: On the contrary, you're clearly insane! You should be in an asylum!

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: How like you. A word of resistance and you slash with your sabre.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: It is lucky for Miss Smith that I do not own a sabre.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: So this is truly your choice?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Lucy has taken care of me for many years. I wish to show my gratitude. She is very determined but Violet has boiled over.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: With the family house? With the family estate? You belong in a straitjacket! To treat your maid as a blood relation is to unpick every fibre of the English way of life.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: What piffle you talk.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Please, there is no need to argue.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I never argue. I explain.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Face it, Violet, I'll outlive you anyway, so it need trouble you no further. And now, I must attend Her Majesty. She stands and leaves. Robert has stood as she goes.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Game, set and match to Lady Bagshaw.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Not while I'm the umpire. Violet has lost her rag. Isobel has not.  87. INT. POLICE STATION. YORK. NIGHT. Ellis is talking to the sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: We had a few drinks and Mr Barrow thought it'd be fun to play a trick on the queers, that's all. He was only in there for five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Dancing the tango with another man.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: Come on, Sergeant. It was a joke. But he sees he needs a new tactic.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Turns your stomach, though.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Relieved to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: I'd rather be dead if I thought I was one of them. But what can I say to the earl?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: What earl?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: The Earl of Grantham. Mr Barrow is his butler. Of course, you'll want to see proof of my identity. He hands over a card. The luckless copper stares at it in horror. EXT. POLICE STATION. YORK. NIGHT. Thomas emerges, looking round. Ellis waves him over.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Was it you who got me out?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: No, the good fairy came down on a moonbeam.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: How did you know where I'd gone?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: The landlord told me. I waited outside, followed you here. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then I showed the sergeant my card, and that seemed to settle things. He is still holding the card which Thomas takes.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: "The Royal Household." He must have loved that. I'm afraid I've been a silly boy.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: You just need to be a bit more circumspect in future, Mr Barrow. He puts his finger to his lips and touches Thomas’. Thoma slips the card into his pocket, which Ellis does not noti He has forgotten about the card completely. INT. EDITH’S BEDROOM. DOWNTON. NIGHT. Edith is having the dress fitted by Lawton, watched by An

dialogues.speaker: LAWTON
dialogues.text: Could you please remove it, m'lady, leaving the pins in place?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Can you really get it done before you go? I don't see how.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: She'll finish it. Won't you?

dialogues.speaker: LAWTON
dialogues.text: I'll do my best.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I'm sure you'll manage. By the way, I think I know what happened to the cupid from the drawing room, m'lady. Edith has stepped out of the dress. Now Lawton takes it.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Really? Was it missing?

dialogues.speaker: LAWTON
dialogues.text: Your dress will be ready in the morning, m'lady.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Thank you. Lawton leaves.  89.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't know how you persuaded her.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: She's nice, really. When you get to know her. Is there anything else? Bertie arrives in a dressing gown as Anna leaves.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Only to say that you're a genius. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I didn't get anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Well, that's that, just because the King doesn't see that a man has any part to play in childbearing.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Well, he doesn't. But you'd think he'd know that one likes to be around.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: You can't just tell him no?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Darling, I'm one of the senior peers in the land. What do you think that means? What do you think I'm sworn to? Edith has nothing to add. INT. MAUD’S BEDROOM. DOWNTON. NIGHT. Maud comes in to find Isobel waiting.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Lady Bagshaw, could I have a word before you ring for your maid? Maud, puzzled, nods. ISOBEL (CONT’D) Does Lucy know that you're her mother? The bomb has dropped. Maud takes a deep breath.  90.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: She does. For years I said I was her godmother, but I told her the truth on her eighteenth birthday.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: How old was she when Jack died?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Six. She'd lived with Jack and his mother until then. But I took her into the house and she went to the village school until, eventually, she became my maid.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: I suppose if she'd been your ward, people would have guessed.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Exactly. Who takes notice of a servant? I hid her in plain sight.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Did you love Jack Smith?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Everyone should know a total love at least once. Jack was mine. My husband was very dull, you know? He wasn't a bad man, but he wasn't a clever one either. And... then he died and Jack came to see me and it began from there. They sit near the fire.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: How daring.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I know it sounds reckless, but I was thirty-nine when I got pregnant. I thought I was barren. Of course, I knew I couldn't tell my father, so I went to America.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: They must have thought that wild.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Little did they know how wild it really was.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: But you were happy with Jack?  91.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Very. We had ten years together before he died. I'd have married him if I'd had the courage. I was weak. But you never knew my father.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: I suppose Royal service kept you silent on the subject.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: In a way. But it was cowardice, really. Now, by making Lucy my heir, I will have taken the first step.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: You must tell Violet at once.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I couldn't.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: You're wrong. As soon as she knows the truth, she'll fathom your plans and cease to fight you. INT. MARY’S BEDROOM. DOWNTON. NIGHT. Anna is looking after Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The servants seemed to be enjoying themselves tonight, especially Molesley. What happened to the Royal team?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: It's a long story, m'lady. But you're right. We did have fun. Mary has tied her dressing gown and sits at a writing des

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well, I'm glad it's gone well for everyone. But I don't think I could face doing it again.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You're not finished yet. You've still got the ball at Harewood.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes, but it won't be our fault if anything goes wrong.  92.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: That's not very cheerful.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The last few days have made me think. Should we really go on with it? We're running the house with too few people as it is. And half of those here now will leave soon.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What are you saying, m'lady?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Isn't it time to chuck in the towel? Lots of people have.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You mean, leave Downton? Mary moves to a chair beside the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We could sell it for a school or an old people's home or something. And buy a manor house with a modest estate, and live a normal life.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Is that what you want?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I want everything to stop being such a struggle. Will the staff stay? Will the farms pay? What are we going to do about the roof? When I was putting up the chairs in the rain, I kept thinking, "What am I doing?"

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what you're doing, m'lady. You're making a centre for the people who work here, for this village, for the county. Downton Abbey is the heart of this community. And you're keeping it beating.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So you think we should battle on?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: While there's blood in your veins. The two women look at each other. This is a pact.  93. INT. BEDROOM GALLERY. DOWNTON. NIGHT. Branson is on his way to bed when Lucy enters the gallery

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Ah, Miss Smith. Is she settled for the night?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: She's more rattled than settled. And I was right. There was an argument, and it was about me.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I hear from Lord Grantham she's planning to alter your life for the better. He says Old Lady Grantham was up in arms.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Are you entitled to your good luck? Do you know why she's doing it?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I do. And I think it's fair.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Go forward in health and use your luck wisely.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I have such a feeling that you can understand what's going on inside my head, when no one else does or ever could. I'll miss our talks.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Would you like to write to me? I could always provide a shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: May I? Really? Branson holds Lucy’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I should be pleased and flattered if you would. He leans in to kiss her. She responds but then pulls back

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: And now I think it's time to say good night, Mr Branson.  She leaves 94.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Good night, Miss Smith. him a much happier man than he was. INT. KITCHEN. DOWNTON. NIGHT. The Downton staff is celebrating victory with plenty of w Andy leads

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Here's to the triumph of Downton and my beautiful wife!

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Here's to all of you who brought it off!

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Here's to Mr Carson for swallowing his principles!

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I shan't sleep a wink tonight.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: And here's to Her Majesty for taking pity on Mr Molesley.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: For a moment there, I thought I was headed for the Tower.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: You're not coming round to them, are you?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It was decent of her, Daisy, when she could have let it spoil things.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: Not everyone's like Robespierre! Let's hear it for the King and Queen.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: The King and Queen! Daisy away from the others.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I've got to tell you something, Daisy. It was me that broke the pump. I don't know what I was doing. I was just in a jealous rage.  95.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It was that plumber you made eyes at. I just saw red. And then when I realised I'd brought him back to the house, I went nearly mad.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I did not make eyes. I liked him, but there was nothing more to it.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I feel a fool now.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: You tried to wreck the visit of the King of England. You risked being sacked, you risked ruin, just for the love of me?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: My feelings took over. That's all I can say. Can you forgive me?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Forgive you? Oh, Andy, I'd have done it myself if I'd had the nerve. Don't you see what it means? We're alike, you and I, full of passion for what matters. I thought you were easily satisfied, but I see now you're not. So we can fight our way to a better world together. EXT. STABLE YARD. DOWNTON. NIGHT. Thomas and Ellis walk away from the car towards the house

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I've shown enough gratitude for what you did.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: We have to stick together, men like us.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: That's the point. I don't know any men like I am. I've never just talked to someone like me.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: We're talking now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it feels good. Just to be two blokes, having a chat, not trying to fit in for once.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: We all have to do what we must to get by. But yes, it feels good to be two ordinary blokes.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Will they ever see it our way?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: I don't know. Fifty years ago, who'd have thought man could fly? EXT. DOWNTON. DAY. A new day has dawned. INT. EDITH’S BEDROOM. DOWNTON. DAY. Bertie wakes. He is alone. EXT. DOWNTON. DAY. Edith walks alone. INT. KITCHEN PASSAGE/BOOT ROOM. DOWNTON. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: LAWTON
dialogues.text: Mrs Bates? Here's the dress.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: We can try it before you leave.

dialogues.speaker: LAWTON
dialogues.text: No need. It'll fit. She hesitates before bringing out a box. LAWTON (CONT’D) Those are the things you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Why do you do it, Miss Lawton? 96. Anna is walking to the servants' hall when Lawton sees he  97.

dialogues.speaker: LAWTON
dialogues.text: Doesn't it ever worry you that on each table in this house there's an ornament that you couldn't buy with a year's wages?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: And what's your answer? Because everyone can't have them, no one should have them?

dialogues.speaker: LAWTON
dialogues.text: No. My answer is, "Why can't I have them? Or some of them." Don't worry. They won't miss what I take. I doubt there's more than one in a hundred will even notice they're gone.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: But they're not yours, Miss Lawton. And they never will be. I'd give it up, if I were you. What if people were to think Her Majesty was light- fingered, if things go missing from every house she stays in?

dialogues.speaker: LAWTON
dialogues.text: Keep your advice for someone who's interested, Mrs Bates. She leaves Anna. INT. SERVANTS’ HALL/ KITCHEN PASSAGE DOWNTON. DAY. The remaining Royal staff and the house servants are havi breakfast. Lawton sits.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Those doors play up something dreadful. They jam and stick for no reason. It's happened to everyone.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Why didn't any of you look for me?

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: I thought I'd seen you go out, Mr Wilson. I'm afraid I was mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: MRS WEBB
dialogues.text: Just as you were mistaken in not waking Monsieur Courbet.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: We thought he'd gone out an' all.  98. Thomas and Ellis arrive together and sit opposite each ot

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: The footmen have telephoned this morning. It seems it was a hoax that took them up to London.

dialogues.speaker: COURBET
dialogues.text: But who would do that?

dialogues.speaker: MRS WEBB
dialogues.text: Who, indeed?

dialogues.speaker: COURBET
dialogues.text: We can investigate when we get to Harewood.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I should be careful, Monsieur Courbet, unless you enjoy ridicule.

dialogues.speaker: COURBET
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I'd say the dinner was a success.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: They sent down their compliments, so I think it must have been. Anna enters and sits.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Well, then. Why call attention to it? Would you show to advantage in this story, do you think?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: But what do we say if we're asked?

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: There was a confusion in London. Monsieur Courbet was ill. If I were you, I wouldn't mention it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Not unless they bring it up.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Quite right. EXT. TEMPLE. DOWNTON GARDENS. DAY. Edith is sitting. Bertie approaches her.  99.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: There you are. I've been looking everywhere. But she doesn’t answer him.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's the matter, darling? Is it something I can help with?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Judging by last night, I doubt it. Edith stands.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just want to own my own life. I want to say things that I think and do what I like.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Don't you now?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: No. I spend my time entertaining people who bore me to death because they're entitled to sit at our table. I attend committees that I haven't chosen because they've chosen me. I used to have a job that I loved, but not anymore. And now my husband won't be there when I have a baby. The woman in the lodge is entitled to that, but I'm not. Bertie takes Edith’s arm. EXT. DOWNTON. DAY. The cars wait outside. INT. HALL. DOWNTON. DAY. Robert walks out of the library to find Carson.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Early warning. Their Majesties are getting ready to leave.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Very good, m'lord. He goes as Edith enters, wearily. Cora is coming downstai  100.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Darling, what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Nothing you can help with.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Can't I try? INT. KITCHEN PASSAGE. DOWNTON. DAY. Carson climbs down the steps to find the staff assembled.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: We should go up. Their Majesties are on their way. They walk to the stairs, passing Ellis. INT. BUTLER’S PANTRY. DOWNTON. DAY Ellis finds Thomas in the pantry.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: So you're off to London?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: They'll drop me at the station.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: I hope we can keep in touch. I feel I've finally found a friend.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: Is that what you've found, Mr Barrow? A friend? Ellis kisses Thomas but just as they kiss -

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Their Majesties are going. The two men spring apart before he finds them with his ey

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: Thanks. Andy leaves and they stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want you to have this. He brings out a key ring with a silver crescent moon fob.  101.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's not much, but I've had it for years. It'll remind you of me. That's the point, isn't it? So you can think of me ‘til we meet again?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mr Ellis, you must come! Ellis hurries away, and Thomas is alone with his key ring EXT. DOWNTON. DAY. Queen Mary walks outside, towards the main car, talking t Cora. Robert and the King also go to the cars. The Royal servants stand to attention. So do the Downton staff. The teams are glaring at each other, unnoticed by their employers.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I hope you enjoy your time at Harewood, sir. The King looks at him. He sighs, slightly resigned.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes. I hope so too.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: It isn't really goodbye when we'll see you all this evening.

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: We're looking forward to the ball. Harewood is such a wonderful house.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, let's mount up , shall we? We'll see you later, Grantham.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Your Majesty. They climb into the cars which drive away. The family goe inside but Robert approaches Carson. ROBERT (CONT’D) Well done, everyone! Shall we head back in? Carson, what happened to the Royal servants last night?  102.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Hard to say, m'lord. They sort of gave up the ghost.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Well, you managed splendidly. Although, I could have done without Molesley's aria. But please thank the staff for saving the day. He goes inside. Carson and Mrs Hughes walk towards the kitchen courtyard, accompanied by Anna.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Mrs Bates...can I ask you something? Anna waits.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What did you give Monsieur Courbet?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: A double dose of a sleeping draught from Mr Bakewell's, in his tea. With this, she walks towards the kitchen courtyard. Molesley is with Baxter.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I made rather a fool of myself last night.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: You could never be a fool to me.

dialogues.speaker: MOLESLEY
dialogues.text: Do you mean that, really?

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: I do. And I think you know how much. INT. KITCHEN PASSAGE/KITCHEN. DOWNTON. DAY. Mrs Patmore and Daisy are busy finishing preparing lunch. Andy walks past in the passage.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: You're right, Mrs Patmore. It's time I started to plan my wedding.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: I don't know what took you so long.  103.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I wasn't sure before. But I am now.

dialogues.speaker: MRS PATMORE
dialogues.text: That's good to hear.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I'm happy, Mrs Patmore. I don't often say that. But I am.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOWNTON. DAY
dialogues.text: Mrs Hughes turns to Carson as he begins to close the oute doors.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Are you very shocked by it all?

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I should be. Interfering with the palace staff on a Royal visit, and me part of it, to boot. I don't know what came over me.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: But?

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: They had it coming to them, Elsie. Let's face it, they had it coming in spades. Hello, what's this? An open car is speeding up the drive. It screeches to a s and Henry Talbot climbs out.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Welcome back, Mr Talbot.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Hello, Carson, Mrs Hughes. Do you know where I'll find Lady Mary?

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: After everything that's gone on, I should think she'll be lying down, sir. They all will be.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Sounds ominous. He goes into the house.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: That's nice, that he's back in time for the ball.  104.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: And thank the Lord we don't have to organise it. They go inside. Carson closes the door. INT. HALL. DOWNTON. DAY. Henry runs up the stairs. INT. MARY’S BEDROOM. DOWNTON. DAY. Mary is hugging Henry tightly. They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh, darling, you don't know what we've lived through.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I couldn't get here sooner. It was the first ship after the last meeting, I promise.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Never mind. You're here now. And I don't have to go to the ball alone like a sad little wallflower.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'll only come if you promise to dance with me non-stop.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It's a deal. They kiss again. EXT. HAREWOOD HOUSE. NIGHT. The great palace blazes with light from every window. Bal guests arrive. INT. HALL/BALLROOM. HAREWOOD HOUSE. NIGHT. The guests are milling about, the men in court dress, the women in tiaras and long gloves. Violet is standing with Isobel. She glances at Maud, who is near the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I suppose Maud has brought that scheming little minx with her.  105.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: If you continue in this vein, you will only make yourself look stupid.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: What I say.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Are you keeping something from me?

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Come with me. The King and Queen are talking to Princess Mary. Lascelle and Maud are nearby.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: Why aren't you happy? I thought you'd be delirious.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: We are happy, if you mean it. Very. But how will you manage Henry?

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: By altering the way we manage each other. And it may not be easy, but I've decided that I'm staying with him.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: I just don't understand what changed your mind.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: It was something Mr Branson said about deciding what matters. For me, the Crown matters more than any of us. I can make it work.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: Branson? The Irish republican?

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: You're well informed.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm better informed than you know. So he persuaded you to do this?

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: We were talking after the parade. Oh, there he is. Say something nice. Please.  106. The King walks through the crowd to where Branson’s stand with Mary and Henry.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: Mr Branson. I wish we had spoken more while we were at Downton Abbey. Branson is completely bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Do you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: Certainly. I believe I have more than one reason to be grateful to you. More than one. He walks on. Branson, dazed, rejoins Henry and Mary.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What was that all about?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'll tell you when we're alone.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: But why more than one? He is amazed. Then he catches sight of the Princess.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who is she?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That's Princess Mary. She was at Downton for the parade yesterday. Didn't you see her?

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: Not at the parade. But I saw her afterwards, at the tea. The Princess nods to him. He gives a neck bow, with a smi Violet, Maud Bagshaw and Isobel sit together.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: So, you see, she has Brompton blood, albeit from an unusual angle.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Why did you not say this long ago?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: It seemed too great a leap for you.  107.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Who do you think I am? Some maiden aunt who's never left the village?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Obviously not.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Don't think I approve, because I don't. But at least I understand. Does Miss Smith know the truth?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Yes, she does. When I get home I will hire another maid, and Lucy can be my companion.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: That's much more suitable.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: And I'm afraid you'll dislike it, but she says that she and Tom Branson have agreed to correspond.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Dislike it? I will lick the stamps myself.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You are amazing, Violet. You haven't won, you know.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I don't believe in defeat. But we can hammer this out when you come back to stay, you and Lucy, when you've finished your tour of duty.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You mean I am once more a member of this family? Violet smiles. The Queen makes a gesture and Maud goes.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: She's right, you know. Brompton is gone. And you must all learn to live with it.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I think we can get it back. For Tom, at least. That's why we need the girl back here.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Oh, Violet. After all these years, you still astonish me.  108.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Good. I'm glad I'm a revelation and not a disappointment. Meanwhile, the King stops Bertie and Edith as they pass.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: There you are, Hexham. I'm sad you can't be part of the Prince's tour. But we'll find something else for you to do.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Sir, I didn't-

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE
dialogues.text: I understood why not as soon as Her Majesty had explained it to me. Edith and Bertie look to the Queen who smiles.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: Congratulations to you both. They drop back. Bertie starts to talk to Henry but we follow Edith who is joined by Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You're looking very sunny tonight.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: I'm happy. Why? Does it bother you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No. But tell me, what are you playing at with Tom and Cousin Maud's famous maid?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I heard you at dinner last night. What are you up to?

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: You know she'll inherit the Brompton estate.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So Mama told me.  109.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: Well, then? Wouldn't you like Tom to have a proper establishment? Mary stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You devious cat. But, for once, they laugh together, until...

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just want a word with Granny. INT. DRAWING ROOM. HAREWOOD. NIGHT. Violet and Mary are together in an empty drawing room. They sit.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How long were you planning to wait before you told us why you really went up to London on Wednesday?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Since you ask, I haven't decided. So, if I tell you now, will you promise to keep it to yourself?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I promise.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Very well. I had some medical tests a few weeks ago, and I went up to London to hear the results.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: And I may not have long to live. It won't be too quick. But, of course, you can never get a London doctor to be precise.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh, Granny.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, no, my dear, save your tears for something sad. There's nothing sad here. I have lived a privileged and an interesting life. And now it's time to go. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm leaving the family and the place that I treasure in talented hands.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I know Papa will be-

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Oh, no. I don't mean your father. I love him dearly. No, I mean you. You are the future of Downton.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But I have such doubts, Granny. Are we right to keep it all going when the world it was built for is fading with every day that passes? Will George and Caroline still be living that life? Are we living it now?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Our ancestors lived different lives from us, and our descendants will live differently again. But Downton Abbey will be part of them.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It won't be the same without you.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Of course it will. You'll take over from where I left off. You'll be the frightening old lady keeping everyone up to the mark.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You will, my darling. And you'll do it wonderfully. You're the best of me that will live on. Hurrah.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh, Granny. I love you so much. But should you be here tonight? Won't you be worn out?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Mary, I can't spend the rest of my life in a shower of, "How are you feeling?" and "Are you quite well?" The point is, I'll be fine until I'm not. That's all there is to it. The door opens and Isobel appears.  111.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: There you are. The dancing's starting. You mustn't miss it.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Thank you. Isobel goes. Mary stands and takes Violet's hand to help up.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You know you'll always be with us, Granny, staring from every picture, talking from every book, as long as the house stands.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: That sounds very exhausting. Do you know, I think I should prefer to rest in peace. Mary laughs. They leave the room. INT. BALLROOM. HAREWOOD HOUSE. NIGHT. Violet and Mary return to the ballroom. The first dance i finishing. Lord Lascelles is with the Queen, the Princess with her father. But now they return to their spouses. It a waltz. Gradually couples join, including Mary and Henry

dialogues.speaker: LASCELLES
dialogues.text: What is it you want?

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: We have things in common. The boys, horses, racing. And there must be more if we look for it. I want us to be friends.

dialogues.speaker: LASCELLES
dialogues.text: We'll have to see.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCESS MARY
dialogues.text: No, dear. We'll have to change. Both of us. Edith and Bertie, Robert and Cora join the dance. The Hex dance by the Granthams.

dialogues.speaker: EDITH
dialogues.text: How did that happen? Was it you, Mama? How did you do it?

dialogues.speaker: CORA
dialogues.text: Simple. Bertie asked the King. I asked the Queen.  112. And the dance spins them apart. CORA (CONT’D) I do love our adventures.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: But isn't it fun when they're over? The Hexhams dance on. Branson sees a figure at the door. is Lucy. He walks over.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I wanted to see the dancing, so I thought I'd pretend I was bringing Lady Bagshaw a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON
dialogues.text: I can give it to her, if you'd like. She holds it and his hand closes on hers before he takes

dialogues.speaker: BRANSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wish you could dance with me. He kisses her hand. She smiles, turns and leaves. Branson takes the handkerchief to Maud Bagshaw, catching Violet's eye. Henry and Mary dance past.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I've got a question for you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Go on?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You'd never want to leave Downton and start up somewhere else, would you? And tell me truthfully.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What brought this on?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Just tell me.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Leave Downton? I think we're stuck with it, aren't we?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes, I believe we are. She looks over to where her grandmother sits, watching, s backed and proud. Mary nods to her. Violet nods back.  113. They understand each other, these two, the past and futur chatelaines of Downton Abbey. INT. HAREWOOD HOUSE. NIGHT. Branson searches empty rooms for Lucy Smith. He sees her terrace.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE. NIGHT.
dialogues.text: The shot widens and we spend a beat each with Robert and Cora, with Henry and Mary, with Edith and Bertie, with th King and Queen, with Isobel and Merton, all talking and dancing, as they spin in the waltz, at the heart of the scene. Branson and Lucy Smith dance together on the terrace. Maud Bagshaw smiles, watching the dancing. Violet smiles, watching Mary dance. EXT. DOWNTON. NIGHT. The front door opens and Carson emerges with Mrs Hughes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: We shouldn't come out this way.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: They won't mind, not this once.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: Well, they've gone and Downton is still standing.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Elsie, a hundred years from now, Downton will still be standing. And the Crawleys will still be here. That is a promise.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUGHES
dialogues.text: We'll see, Charlie. We'll see. He holds out his arm. She smiles and takes it. Together, walk away from the great house.
